title: 'Will do everything to avoid trade war': How world leaders reacted to Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs - (Published 9 hour(s), 36 minute(s) ago)
content: Italy's conservative Premier Giorgia Meloni described the new 20 per cent tariffs against the European Union as “wrong,” saying they benefit neither side.
resumen:
World leaders reacted to Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs. President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on nearly all US trading partners — a 34 per cent tax on imports from China and 20 per cent on the European Union, among others.

The British government said the United States remains the UK's “closest ally.” Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds said the UK hoped to strike a trade deal to “mitigate the impact” of the 10% tariffs on British goods announced by Trump. Reynolds said, "Nobody wants a trade war and our intention remains to secure a deal," and added that "But nothing is off the table and the government will do everything necessary to defend the UK's national interest.”.

Italy's conservative Premier Giorgia Meloni described the new 20 per cent tariffs against the European Union as “wrong,” saying they benefit neither side. Meloni said, “We will do everything we can to work towards an agreement with the United States, with the aim of avoiding a trade war that would inevitably weaken the West in favour of other global players”.

Brazil's government said it was considering taking the case to the World Trade Organization. Brazil's Congress unanimously passed a reciprocity bill to allow its government to retaliate against any country or trade bloc that imposes tariffs on Brazilian goods.

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the US tariffs imposed on his country were totally unwarranted, but Australia will not retaliate. Albanese said, “President Trump referred to reciprocal tariffs. A reciprocal tariff would be zero, not 10 per cent”.

New Zealand trade minister Todd McClay said New Zealand was “a very low tariff regime” and the correct figure was below the 10 per cent baseline rate applied by the US to all countries. McClay said, “We won't be looking to retaliate. That would put up prices on New Zealand consumers and it would be inflationary”.

Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum said she would wait to take action on Thursday when it was clear how Trump's announcement would affect Mexico.

Canada had imposed retaliatory tariffs in response to the 25 per cent tariffs that Trump tied to the trafficking of fentanyl. The European Union, in response to the steel and aluminum tariffs, imposed taxes on 26 billion euros' worth (USD 28 billion) of US goods, including bourbon, prompting Trump to threaten a 200 per cent tariff on European alcohol.

title: Trump Says Global Trade Is Unfair. Does He Have a Point? - (Published 13 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump says that countries have been ripping off the United States for decades. There is some truth to that argument — but also a lot of hypocrisy.
resumen:
President Trump has accused America’s trading partners of undermining the United States for decades, saying they have engaged in unfair trade practices to steal the country’s wealth and enrich their own economies. He has set his sights not only on adversaries like China, but also traditional allies like Canada and Europe. Mr. Trump has promised to correct this situation on Wednesday, when he announces expansive tariffs on foreign products.

The United States has long been more open to trade than many countries globally. Some countries do have tough trade barriers to U.S. exports, or economic policies that distort global markets — particularly China.

Mr. Trump’s claims include a heavy dose of exaggeration, as well as hypocrisy. Mr. Trump has singled out high tariff rates that countries charge on certain U.S. exports including Europe’s tax on cars and India’s levy on motorcycles. But the United States also has high tariff rates that it charges on certain imports, such as a 25 percent fee on light trucks. Mr. Trump has lumped in friendly allies like Canada, which have some limits to U.S. exports outside a few sectors, with nations like China, which have extensive trade barriers.

The trade measures that Mr. Trump has introduced so far have more than tripled the estimated dollar value of tariffs that importers must pay to bring products into the United States compared with last year. In his first term, Mr. Trump’s collective tariff actions on foreign metals, China and other products ended up doubling U.S. tariffs.

Mr. Trump is referring to his plan to impose reciprocal tariffs as “Liberation Day.”

William Reinsch, a senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, called the president’s claims about trade “a huge exaggeration.”

Data from the World Trade Organization showed the United States had a trade-weighted average tariff rate of 2.2 percent in 2023, compared with 2.7 percent for the European Union, 1.9 percent in Japan, 3.4 percent for Canada, 3 percent for China and 1.7 percent for Switzerland. India’s trade-weighted average tariff rate is 12 percent, while Mexico’s is 3.9 percent and Vietnam’s is 5.1 percent.

The United States levies individual tariff rates on about 13,000 foreign products. The U.S. trades with almost 200 countries.

India charges a 50 percent tariff on imported motorcycles, a 60 percent tariff on automobiles and a 150 percent tariff on alcoholic beverages. Canada’s dairy system charges a high tariff after a certain volume of imports is reached, a system known as a tariff-rate quota. Goods imported from the United States above quota levels “are subject to prohibitively high tariffs,” like 245 percent for cheese and 298 percent for butter. The European Union charges a 50 percent tariff on American dairy and Japan charges a 700 percent tariff on American rice.

The United States charges 350 percent tariffs on tobacco from many countries, 260 percent tariffs on Irish butter substitutes and 197 percent tariffs on Chinese stainless steel kitchenware. The United States also has relatively high tariffs on peanuts, apparel, footwear and sugar.

China has wielded huge subsidies and other economic practices that give its industries a competitive advantage. Beijing’s approach has fueled the growth of a $1 trillion-plus trade surplus. The Office of the United States Trade Representative said this week that China had used industrial planning and other policies to target sectors like robotics, aerospace, new energy vehicles and biopharmaceuticals for “domination.”

Mr. Trump has placed an additional 25 percent tariff on many products from Canada, but only an additional 20 percent tariff on goods from China.

title: Cities in states won by Trump would be most hurt by Canadian tariffs, analysis finds: Milwaukee is #10 - (Published 15 hour(s), 8 minute(s) ago)
content: A study by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce found 1,595 companies in the Milwaukee metro area export to Canada.
resumen:
A new analysis released last week by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce detailed the areas most dependent on exports to Canada, with San Antonio and Detroit topping the list of 41 U.S. metro areas. The findings show that the United States’ 25% tariffs on Canada and Canada’s retaliations could inflict meaningful damage in key states for U.S. politics.

Nearly half of what San Antonio exports, with its aerospace, auto and energy sectors, goes to Canada. About 40% of what the auto-driven Detroit area exports also goes to Canada. Trump’s wins in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin were crucial for his overall victory in November’s presidential election — and Milwaukee and Pittsburgh also rank in the top 10 for exposure to a trade war with Canada.

The Milwaukee metropolitan area ranked #10. The Chamber found exports to Canada represent $2.1 billion of the $9.4 billion worth of goods exported and 2% of the metro’s entire gross domestic product (GDP).

The U.S. International Trade Administration says 2,812 companies in the Milwaukee metro area export their products to other countries, and 1,595 of them export to North American trade partners.

The analysis was conducted before the Republican president announced March 26 that he was placing additional 25% tariffs on imported autos and parts starting on April 3.

April 3 is also when a slate of additional, but unknown tariffs are expected to be announced, what Trump has dubbed “Liberation Day.”

Trump has placed 25% tariffs on many goods from Mexico and Canada, with a lower 10% tax on energy products and potash from Canada. Some of those tariffs have been suspended or delayed, though they’re set to fully hit in April.

Canadian leaders have warned that the United States would suffer in the form of higher prices, fewer jobs and slower growth because of the trade war. But an analysis by the Brookings Institution found that the economic pain would be more severe in Mexico and Canada because those countries are more reliant on the United States in terms of trade.

Trump’s stated reason for the tariffs is to stop illegal immigration and drug smuggling, though he’s also said that he dislikes the trade deficit with both countries and has taunted Canada by suggesting that it could become the 51st U.S. state.

title: A Tequila Ban a Century Ago Predicts the Chaos of Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 12 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: Trump’s threat to impose tariffs on Mexico undermines his stated intention to eliminate the “chaos” at America’s southern border.
resumen:
President Trump’s Mexico agenda mostly revolves around his obsession with what he calls the “chaos” at the border. His proposed solution of tariffs is bound to generate chaos at the border by creating powerful incentives for black market trade.

The Trump administration announced a slew of tariffs affecting many countries. He has previously threatened steep tariffs on Mexican products, arguing that the punitive move will force Mexico to address the problems caused by drug smuggling into the United States. A sudden spike in the price of all goods coming from Mexico will only create an opening for criminal organizations to smuggle a wider range of products and expand their power.

International sanctions led Russia to rely on a dark fleet of aging oil tankers sailing without insurance, and crackdowns on electronic money transfers by criminal organizations boosted cryptocurrency.

America’s effort to halt the importation of tequila a century ago is also illustrative. During Prohibition, the campaign to stop Mexican spirits from being brought across our southern border unleashed violence, gave rise to what could be considered the first Mexican cartels and made tequila only more popular.

At the start of the 20th century, the boundary between the United States and Mexico was largely notional. The tequila maker José Cuervo began to forge an empire by focusing on American drinkers.

After Villa staged a bloody cross-border raid, Gen. John J. Pershing led about 10,000 U.S. troops into Mexico in pursuit.

When Germany offered to ally with Mexico and against the United States, President Woodrow Wilson responded by entering World War I — and by banning commerce with Mexican companies with too much “German influence.” Cuervo’s tequila company was banned in 1918. That same year, the first section of border fence was erected and soon, the creation of a border patrol was authorized. Under the guise of preserving grains for food, the manufacture and importation of all hard liquor was also legally banned — and the black market exploded.

Cuervo banded together the owners of Sauza and Herradura to form a union organized on a German cooperative model — the cartel. It transported goods by rail to border towns, where smugglers carried bottles across on foot, in the trunks of cars, and through the open desert in donkey straddles and pack saddles.

The United States expanded enforcement and built more fencing in an effort to block the shipments, and the country’s foray into Prohibition in January 1920 extended import and sales bans nationally. Two months later, 25,000 empty tequila bottles were found in El Paso, all bearing the Cuervo label and all headed back to Mexico to be refilled and carried across again. The United States cracked down even harder — especially along the Rio Grande, where the shoot-first mentality of the Texas Rangers led to pitched gun battles across the desert and brush country.

In December 1929, as the first decade of Prohibition drew to a close, the editors of The Washington Herald tallied 1,360 deaths “through official violence,” with some of the highest numbers in El Paso — more than Al Capone’s Chicago. The border region of Texas accounted for roughly 8 percent of all Prohibition-related deaths nationwide by then.

Cuervo’s tequila cartel unraveled after his death in 1921, bringing violence to the Mexican side of the border, too, as families vied for greater control of the trade and fractured into smaller cartels.

Cuervo, Sauza and Herradura are still some of the world’s leading tequila sellers. More than two-thirds of tequila produced last year went to the United States. That’s $4.5 billion worth.

Tequila makers worry that tariffs would not only strangle legitimate trade but also rekindle the black market. Brands producing premium products are especially concerned: The more expensive the item, the greater the incentive for thieves to steal it. Bandits are targeting “anything that goes up in price,” says Guillermo Erickson Sauza, a great-great-grandson of the founder of Sauza Tequila, whose products regularly sell for hundreds of dollars per bottle. He has had three truckloads hijacked on the American side of the border in the last year and a half and says the tariffs will “absolutely” increase the risk of such thefts.

People in villages like Boquillas del Carmen live quietly along the river, selling trinkets and tequila to tourists who enter via the official checkpoint. Cartels thrive on smuggling migrants and illicit drugs through a few defined border corridors. That could change drastically if Mr. Trump’s actions lead to a black market for all Mexican goods. His tariffs may help fill the coffers of the federal government and underwrite his tax cuts, but they also risk plunging the southern U.S. border back into turmoil — increasing smuggling, putting money in the pockets of gangs and cartels on both sides of the border and further escalating the cycle of enforcement.

Building a massive border apparatus hasn’t worked. A century ago it didn’t keep José Cuervo out of the United States; it made him a household name. And the company he started is still tequila’s largest manufacturer, under the principal ownership of Juan Beckmann Vidal, the grandson of the German consul whose foreign ties prompted America’s first ban. He now owns condos in Trump Tower.

resumen: La administración de Donald Trump ha implementado una política exterior hacia Latinoamérica y Venezuela de aislamiento y endurecimiento. La Ley de Enemigos Extranjeros convierte al régimen de Caracas, al Tren de Aragua y carteles de droga en agentes de daño. La política de Trump hacia la región es una combinación de pragmatismo y presión, con imposición de aranceles y sanciones que afectan relaciones comerciales y diplomáticas. Trump busca el control del canal de Panamá, la paz en Ucrania, y la transición en Venezuela. Se impusieron aranceles del 25% a países que compren petróleo venezolano, afectando a India (Reliance), Repsol, Maurel y Prom, y Global Oil Terminals. La administración Trump ha revocado licencias a empresas estadounidenses en Venezuela, y ha deportado a venezolanos sospechosos de actividades delictivas. Trump es más popular que en su mandato anterior, con un 45% de respaldo. La estrategia de Trump hacia Venezuela obedece a una agenda de seguridad, con medidas en frontera y búsqueda de criminales. La administración Trump ha dado reconocimiento a líderes opositores, exigiendo seguridad para María Corina Machado y Edmundo González (a quien reconoce como Presidente electo de Venezuela). La política de Trump busca acelerar una transición democrática en Venezuela. Trump, Europa, Canadá, Israel, Argentina y otras democracias saben que un cambio de gobierno en Venezuela permitiría una cooperación más efectiva contra el crimen organizado y grupos terroristas. El régimen de Maduro ha contado con el apoyo de Rusia, China e Irán. Trump ha priorizado la normalización de relaciones con Rusia, ha sido cauteloso con China, exigió a Ucrania la devolución de ayuda financiera, y ha tenido tensiones comerciales y políticas con Europa. La imposición de aranceles por parte de EE.UU. supone un tablero complejo. La diferencia entre Trump I y Trump II con relación a Venezuela es que ahora se observan decisiones progresivas, duras y firmes. Trump cierra el grifo en Venezuela, pone barreras a Canadá y México, se desmarca de China, disciplina la OTAN, cierra sus fronteras, y le declara la guerra al crimen organizado. Los estadounidenses aprueban esta agenda en un 45%. El cierre de grifos está generando un efecto importante en Venezuela, Cuba y el resto del continente.

title: Trump’s New Tariffs Test Apple’s Global Supply Chain - (Published 13 hour(s), 55 minute(s) ago)
content: The iPhone maker spent years trying to move production of some products out of China to avoid tariffs. But now that may not matter.
resumen:
In 2018, when President Trump first pushed tariffs on China, Apple began moving more production of iPads and AirPods to Vietnam and iPhones to India.

On Wednesday, Mr. Trump said that the United States would put tariffs of 46 percent on Vietnam and 26 percent on India. The White House has said the tariffs are effective immediately.

The company is already dealing with 20 percent tariffs on products imported from China, where Apple makes about 90 percent of the iPhones it sells around the world. Mr. Trump said that the rate would go to 34 percent under his new tariff plan.

The iPhones, iPads and Apple Watches that the company sells deliver three-quarters of its nearly $400 billion in annual revenue.

The tariffs on iPhones and other devices imported from China will increase Apple’s annual costs by $8.5 billion, according to Morgan Stanley. That would reduce the company’s profit next year by $0.52 per share, or about $7.85 billion. That would be a roughly 7 percent hit on next year’s profits.

Apple’s stock fell 5.7 percent in aftermarket trading following Mr. Trump’s remarks.

In February, Apple followed through on that promise by pledging to invest $500 billion in the country.

In 2017, as Mr. Trump started in office, Apple began setting up assembly lines for iPhones in India. It is in the process of increasing production there, with hopes the country’s factories manufacture about 25 percent of the 200 million iPhones that it sells annually.

The company also began shifting production of AirPods, iPads and MacBooks to Vietnam. Vietnam’s factories accounted for more than 10 percent of the top 200 suppliers that the company had in 2023.

title: Lo dice el Reportero - (Published 12 hour(s), 6 minute(s) ago)
content: La Casa Blanca publicó un artículo en el que destaca los beneficios económicos de los aranceles implementados en el primer periodo de Donald Trump.
resumen: Donald Trump firmó la “orden ejecutiva histórica que instituye aranceles recíprocos a países de todo el mundo”. Al iniciar su discurso de este miércoles, acusó que durante décadas Estados Unidos "ha sido realmente saqueado, robado y estafado por amigos, enemigos, todo el mundo". El Presidente Donald Trump anunció sus planes de imponer aranceles radicales como represalia a los socios comerciales de Estados Unidos (EU) en una ceremonia en el Jardín de las Rosas. Trump anunció un impuesto de 25 por ciento sobre todos los autos que son exportados a Estados Unidos. Trump afirmó que también establecerá un arancel base universal del 10 por ciento que se aplicará a todos los países, además de las cifras ya anunciadas. Esto significa que un país como China se enfrentará a un arancel del 44 por ciento, adicional al 20 por ciento que el magnate ya ha impuesto. El Presidente de Estados Unidos señaló que impondrá al Reino Unido un arancel del 10 por ciento. Trump destacó que Estados Unidos calculará un arancel para otros países basándose en aranceles y “otras formas de fraude”. China se enfrentará a un gravamen del 34 por ciento, mientras que la Unión Europea (UE) tendrá uno del 20 por ciento, Japón del 24 por ciento e India del 26 por ciento. “Este es el Día de la Liberación que hemos esperado tanto tiempo. El 2 de abril será recordado como el día en que la industria de Estados Unidos volvió a nacer. Nos han engañado durante más de 50 años, pero no va a volver a ocurrir”, sentenció el republicano. En el evento, el multimillonario firmó una “orden ejecutiva histórica que instituye aranceles recíprocos a países de todo el mundo”, los cuales comenzarán a aplicarse a partir de esta media noche. "Recíproco, ¿qué significa? Ellos nos lo hacen a nosotros y nosotros a ellos. Así de simple. No podría ser más sencillo este asunto", detalló el mandatario de Estados Unidos. Desde la Casa Blanca, insistió en que se "trata de uno de los días más importantes en la historia estadounidense". Trump confió en que los trabajos y las fábricas regresen a su país. Donald Trump denunció que países de todo el mundo impusieron barreras comerciales a Estados Unidos durante las últimas décadas, y que su Nación no gravó sus importaciones. Donald Trump acusa que según Estados Unidos ha sido estafado y robado por décadas, previo a la imposición de aranceles. Trump denunció que países de todo el mundo impusieron barreras comerciales a Estados Unidos durante las últimas décadas, y que su Nación no gravó sus importaciones. "Venden mucho adentro de nuestro país y nosotros no les vendemos tanto", indicó. Puso el ejemplo de los gravámenes impuestos en las motocicletas estadounidenses. Trump dijo que no se puede pagar el déficit de Canadá, de México y de tantos países. La Casa Blanca publicó un artículo titulado "Los aranceles funcionan, y el primer mandato del Presidente Trump lo demuestra", en el que destaca los beneficios económicos y estratégicos para Estados Unidos gracias a las tarifas implementadas. Un estudio de 2024 reveló que los aranceles aplicados por Trump "fortalecieron la economía de EU y llevaron a una relocalización significativa en industrias como la manufactura y la producción de acero". Además, un informe de 2023 de la Comisión de Comercio Internacional de EU confirmó que los aranceles redujeron las importaciones desde China, impulsaron la producción nacional y apenas afectaron los precios finales. Entre los logros más destacados, el Gobierno estadounidense resaltó  que  los aranceles contribuyeron a una inversión de más de 15.7 millones de dólares en nuevas instalaciones de acero, creando al menos tres mil 200 empleos directos. Además, un análisis económico de 2024 estimó que un arancel global del 10 por ciento podría generar un crecimiento económico de 728 mil millones, crear 2.8 millones de empleos y aumentar los ingresos reales de los hogares en un 5.7 por ciento. La Casa Blanca enfatizó que, a pesar de las críticas iniciales por parte de los medios y algunos economistas, los aranceles han demostrado ser una herramienta eficaz para fortalecer la economía estadounidense y fomentar el consumo de productos nacionales.

title: Paper touts trade benefits for US in last-ditch tariffs appeal - (Published 14 hour(s), 30 minute(s) ago)
content: China highlights US farmers and tech companies as beneficiaries of economic ties in an apparent appeal to cool trade tensions on the eve of Donald Trump's expected announcement of new global tariffs.
resumen:
China highlights US farmers and tech companies as beneficiaries of economic ties in an apparent appeal to cool trade tensions on the eve of Donald Trump’s expected announcement of new global tariffs.

Agricultural imports from the United States have brought “tangible benefits” for both sides by meeting China’s demand and boosting American farmers’ income, according to an article published yesterday by the People’s Daily.

The piece was credited to Zhong Sheng, a Chinese homonym for “Voice of China” often used to set out Beijing’s foreign policy views.

The article is the second in a series of commentaries on China-US ties seemingly timed with the US President’s plan to impose reciprocal tariffs.

The first piece on Monday named Tesla Inc and Apple Inc as examples of how China’s vast market and manufacturing capabilities have made it an indispensable partner of US firms.

The article struck a conciliatory tone, calling for greater China-US cooperation despite their competition.

Beijing targeted US agricultural and energy goods in its retaliation against the 20% blanket tariffs imposed on Chinese products by Trump this year.

Chinese authorities also launched an antitrust investigation into Alphabet Inc’s Google and put US gene-sequencing company Illumina Inc on a so-called blacklist of entities.

China’s top diplomat on Tuesday denounced the broad tariffs the United States imposed over Beijing’s alleged role in America’s fentanyl crisis, calling for Trump to remove the levies in an interview with Russian state-run news service RIA Novosti.

Foreign Minister Wang Yi said, “If the United States persists in exerting pressure and even continues to engage in blackmail, China will resolutely counteract it.”

content: Quito, 2 abr (EFE).- El Gobierno de Ecuador destacó que los aranceles del 10 % impuestos este miércoles por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se encuentran dentro del nivel más bajo de ...
resumen: El Gobierno de Ecuador destacó que los aranceles del 10 % impuestos el 2 de abril de 2025 por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se encuentran dentro del nivel más bajo de sanciones comerciales que el mandatario estadounidense ha impuesto a nivel global. El Ministerio de Producción, Comercio Exterior, Inversiones y Pesca del Gobierno presidido por Daniel Noboa resaltó que Ecuador ha recibido únicamente el arancel del 10 %, sin medidas adicionales ni sanciones particulares. El arancel mínimo del 10 % entrará en vigor el sábado 5 de abril. Los aranceles para Venezuela fueron del 15 % y para Nicaragua del 18 %. El Gobierno de Ecuador anticipó que continuará fortaleciendo las relaciones con Estados Unidos, principal socio comercial de Ecuador. Los aranceles globales impuestos por Trump se dieron cuatro días después del encuentro privado que tuvo con Noboa en Mar-a-Lago (Florida). Noboa buscó propiciar este encuentro en el marco de la campaña electoral en la que está inmersa Ecuador, donde el presidente y candidato a la reelección se enfrenta en la segunda vuelta a la candidata presidencial del correísmo, Luisa González. Noboa consideró el martes -durante una entrevista a Radio Sucesos- que desde el Gobierno ecuatoriano se está "haciendo los deberes" para que Trump no sancionase al país andino dentro de los nuevos aranceles globales, pues no existe tratado de libre comercio entre ambos países. En 2024, la balanza comercial de Ecuador con Estados Unidos tuvo un déficit de 644,5 millones de dólares, al registrar exportaciones por valor de 7.024 millones de dólares e importaciones por valor de 7.668 millones de dólares. Si se retira de la ecuación el petróleo y sus derivados, el intercambio comercial tuvo un superávit para Ecuador de 2.306 millones de dólares, al registrar exportaciones por valor de 5.043 millones de dólares e importaciones por valor de 2.737 millones de dólares. Después del petróleo, los productos más exportados desde Ecuador a Estados Unidos en 2024 fueron los camarones (langostinos), con envíos por valor de 1.546 millones de dólares; el banano, con 512 millones de dólares; y el cacao y sus derivados, con 484 millones de dólares.

title: ‘Liberation Day’: A timeline of Donald Trump’s trade war with Canada - (Published 13 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: For over a year before the November 2024 presidential election, Donald Trump had been signalling plans to impose across-the-board tariffs if he won the United States presidency. Trump was elected on ...
resumen:
Donald Trump had been signalling plans to impose across-the-board tariffs if he won the United States presidency for over a year before the November 2024 presidential election.

Trump was elected on Nov. 5, and it’s been a roller-coaster ever since for Canadian leaders and businesses. He has threatened, enacted, modified and delayed multiple rounds of tariffs only to announce additional protectionist trade policies are to come.

The duties are widely seen as inflationary in the U.S., and with Canada’s retaliatory tariffs enacted in response, inflation is also a risk north of the border. Meanwhile, tariffs are likely to weigh on both economies and could even cause a recession.

The Canadian dollar began sliding in the fall of last year and has been hovering around 70 cents US in recent months. Stock markets in Canada and the U.S. have whipsawed with every new piece of tariff news and traditional haven investments like gold have soared in value amid the uncertainty.

Here’s a timeline of the key dates in Trump’s tariff journey after he was elected president:

*   **Nov. 25, 2024:** Trump pledges to impose a 25 per cent tariff on all Canadian and Mexican imports, saying they would come into force on inauguration day, Jan. 20. He says in a post on Truth Social, a social media site he owns, that the tariffs would remain until both countries stop drugs, particularly fentanyl, and people from illegally crossing American borders.
*   **Dec. 11:** After Canadian premiers met with then-Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, they confirm the country is preparing retaliatory tariffs in response to Trump’s threat. Securing an exemption or lower levies on energy exports is among the priorities.
*   **Jan. 20, 2025:** On his inauguration day, Trump says tariffs will likely come on Feb. 1 rather than taking immediate effect. He also signs an executive order to enact an “America First Trade Policy,” calling for his trade and commerce officials to report back to him by April 1 on a sweeping review of U.S. trade policy and relationships. The date does not come with a default imposition of any tariffs, but does direct Trump’s administration to begin examining the Canada-U.S.-Mexico free-trade agreement, which Trump signed in 2018, ahead of a planned 2026 review.
*   **Feb. 1:** Trump signs an order on Feb. 1 — a Saturday — imposing blanket tariffs of 25 per cent on virtually all goods entering the U.S. from Canada and Mexico, and a reduced 10 per cent tariff on energy, set to take effect on Feb. 4. Trump’s Feb. 1 order also imposes 10 per cent tariffs on goods entering the U.S. from China. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau outlines Canada’s planned retaliation strategy, including immediate counter-tariffs that would take effect the same day U.S. tariffs kick in. Over the weekend, Canadian provinces start pulling American alcohol from liquor-store shelves at provincially owned distributors.
*   **Feb. 3:** Trump pauses the implementation of tariffs on Canadian goods for one month after Ottawa pledges action to secure the border. He does the same for Mexico.
*   **Feb. 10:** Trump signs a plan to institute 25 per cent tariffs on all steel and aluminum entering the U.S. starting March 12, ending previous exemptions for Canada. Trump previously imposed tariffs on the metals in 2018 but later exempted Canada and Mexico.
*   **Feb. 11:** Trump says the steel and aluminum tariffs would stack on top of other levies, including the paused 25 per cent tariffs on all Canadian goods other than energy.
*   **Feb. 14:** Trump had previously threatened to levy tariffs on imported automobiles coming into the U.S. He says on Feb. 14 that tariffs on imported automobiles could come “around April 2,” adding the following week that the levies would be “in the neighbourhood of 25 per cent.” Around the same time, he floated imposing similar tariffs on pharmaceuticals and semiconductors, but has yet to provide a timeline for those.
*   **Feb. 27:** In a Truth Social post, Trump says that April 2 would mark the start of what he terms “reciprocal” tariffs, which would apply to goods coming in from countries that have tariffs or other barriers on U.S. goods. These would be on top of other tariffs and would match the rates charged by other countries, including subsidies and value-added taxes. He had signed a memorandum on Feb. 13 directing his trade czar to examine what he perceives as unfair trade practices from other nations.
*   **March 4:** Trump’s tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods go ahead after the month-long pause. There had been hopes that the border security measures Canada took could stave off the tariffs, but on March 3, Trump confirmed they would go ahead, which they did. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced broad retaliatory tariffs on U.S. goods including food, alcohol, furniture, paper and more.
*   **March 5:** Trump pledges a one-month exemption for vehicles traded under the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement, also known as CUSMA. White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt says during a briefing that the move comes after the Big Three automakers — Stellantis, Ford and General Motors — asked for an exemption.
*   **March 6:** Finance Minister Dominic LeBlanc says Ottawa will suspend its second wave of retaliatory tariffs after Trump signed an executive order to pause some new duties on Canada and Mexico and reduce potash levies to 10 per cent. Trump’s order links the tariff relief to maintaining the flow of automobile parts that comply with CUSMA and to helping farmers who need potash for fertilizer. An explanatory statement issued by the White House says there would be no tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico that claim and qualify for CUSMA preference.
*   **March 10:** Ontario Premier Doug Ford announces the immediate application of a 25 per cent surcharge on electricity exports to the U.S. as part of the province’s retaliation to Trump’s tariffs. Trump responds aggressively, saying he will double the rate on steel and aluminum tariffs set to be implemented March 12 to 50 per cent. He says on Truth Social that the move is in response to Ontario placing a 25 per cent surcharge on electricity it exports to the U.S. However, Ford agrees to suspend the province’s export tax later the same day.
*   **March 12:** The 25 per cent tariffs on steel and aluminum tariffs from all countries take effect. Canada hits the U.S. with a second tranche of retaliatory tariffs, enacting 25 per cent tariffs on $29.8 billion in U.S. goods, targeting steel and aluminum as well as other products including computers, sports equipment and cast iron goods.

content: Un 30% de las exportaciones del país se vería afectado por los aranceles del 10% impuestos por el Gobierno de Estados Unidos, aunque los expertos aseguran que su impacto deberá ser medido producto por ...
resumen: El Gobierno de Estados Unidos ha anunciado un arancel del 10% para todos los productos colombianos que aspiren a entrar en el mercado estadounidense. La tarifa colombiana es la más baja, en comparación con China (34%) y otras naciones. Esto genera incertidumbre sobre la seguridad jurídica para las inversiones consignada en el Tratado de Libre Comercio que mantienen los dos países desde 2012. Germán Umaña, primer ministro de Comercio de Petro, asegura que el capítulo de las inversiones está blindado. Fedesarrollo calcula que un 30% de las exportaciones del país están expuestas. Negocios como el banano o las flores colombianas podrían salir lesionados. La Cámara Colombo Americana señala que, al ser una medida global, el escenario quedaría nivelado. La idea del presidente Trump es equilibrar las cargas fiscales de su país, eliminando subsidios y replanteando inversiones. Los mayores socios comerciales de Estados Unidos han recibido las tarifas más altas: China (34%), Japón (24%) y la Unión Europea (20%). María Claudia Lacouture, presidente de la cámara Colombo Americana, sugiere fortalecer la productividad, la promoción y la diversificación de los mercados. La canciller Laura Sarabia ha asumido la vocería del Gobierno, destacando que la decisión afecta a todos los países y que ya se encuentra en conversaciones para proteger a los exportadores locales. Germán Umaña afirma que los impuestos de aduana estadounidenses "acaban con los tratados de libre comercio, causando un desorden total a nivel mundial", pero Colombia es uno de los países menos afectados. El objetivo último de Trump es reducir las exportaciones chinas y fortalecer la inversión en Norteamérica. Umaña vaticina una contracción del mercado mundial y afectación sobre la actividad comercial de los países desarrollados.

title: With Trump’s Tariffs, the Chasm Between Allies and the U.S. Widens - (Published 12 hour(s), 47 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump announced sweeping levies on countries across the world. Washington’s partners have been bracing for the fallout.
resumen:
President Donald Trump announced new tariffs on Wednesday. His plan, which he is calling “reciprocal,” would impose a wave of tariffs on dozens of countries. The European Union will face 20 percent tariffs, Japan and South Korea will face tariffs of 24 and 26 percent respectively, and China will absorb an additional 34 percent on top of existing levies.

Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said the global economy will massively suffer.

China condemned the tariffs as a “unilateral” violation of international rules.

Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba called the tariffs “extremely regrettable.”

In South Korea, the acting president, Han Duck-soo, convened an emergency task force.

Wendy Cutler, a former U.S. trade negotiator, said Asian countries in particular have been hard hit.

Vietnam now faces a levy of 46 percent.

Exiger calculated that the burden from the tariffs could fall heaviest on Chinese exports, which would face $149 billion in additional surcharges, while Vietnamese goods would face $63 billion, Taiwanese products $37 billion and Japanese goods $36 billion.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia said the United States imposing 10 percent tariffs on the country had “no basis in logic.”

Luis de la Calle, a top Mexican trade economist, said it was good news for Mexico and Canada that they would not be subject to new tariffs beyond those previously announced.

title: Trump announces sweeping new tariffs to promote US manufacturing, risking inflation and trade wars - (Published 7 hour(s), 14 minute(s) ago)
content: President Donald Trump declared on Wednesday a 10% baseline tax on imports from all countries and higher tariff rates on dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the United States, threatening ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday a 10% baseline tax on imports from all countries and higher tariff rates on dozens of nations that run trade surpluses with the United States.

Trump said the United States would charge a 34% tax on imports from China, a 20% tax on imports from the European Union, 25% on South Korea, 24% on Japan and 32% on Taiwan.

Trump declared a national economic emergency to launch the tariffs, expected to produce hundreds of billions in annual revenues.

Trump imposed “reciprocal” tariffs on trade partners, acting without Congress through the 1977 International Emergency Powers Act.

The president’s higher rates would hit foreign entities that sell more goods to the United States than they buy, meaning the tariffs could stay in place for some time as the administration expects other nations to lower their tariffs and other barriers to trade that it says have led to a $1.2 trillion trade imbalance last year.

The tariffs follow similar recent announcements of 25% taxes on auto imports; levies against China, Canada and Mexico; and expanded trade penalties on steel and aluminum.

Trump has also imposed tariffs on countries that import oil from Venezuela and he plans separate import taxes on pharmaceutical drugs, lumber, copper and computer chips.

Senior administration officials said the taxes would raise hundreds of billions of dollars annually in revenues.

The White House could not say whether the tariff exemptions on imports worth $800 or less would remain in place.

Heather Boushey, a member of the Biden White House’s Council of Economic Advisers, noted that the less aggressive tariffs Trump imposed during his first term failed to stir the manufacturing renaissance he promised voters.

Rep. Suzan DelBene, D-Wash., said the tariffs are “part of the chaos and dysfunction” being generated across the Trump administration.

House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La. said the tariffs could disrupt an economy with an otherwise healthy 4.1 % unemployment rate.

Canada has imposed some countermeasures in response to the 25% tariffs that Trump tied to the trafficking of fentanyl.

The European Union, in response to the steel and aluminum tariffs, put taxes on 26 billion euros’ worth ($28 billion) of U.S. goods.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said that the EU has a strong plan to retaliate and will use it if necessary.

Italy’s premier, Giorgia Meloni, reiterated her call to avoid an EU-US trade war.

Ray Sparnaay, general manager of JE Fixture & Tool, a Canadian tool and die business, said the uncertainty has crushed his company’s ability to make plans.

title: Here's how Trump's 'half-baked tariffs' could impact the Kentucky bourbon industry - (Published 13 hour(s), 55 minute(s) ago)
content: In Trump's "Liberation Day" speech, he announced blanket 10% tariffs and additional country specific tariffs. Here's how it could impact KY bourbon ...
resumen:
President Trump announced a new round of tariffs on Wednesday, including a baseline 10% tariff on goods from most countries and additional tariffs on specific countries.

The tariffs are intended to boost American manufacturing and create jobs, but economists warn they could lead to higher prices for consumers.

The bourbon industry, a major part of the Kentucky economy, could be caught in the crossfire if other countries retaliate with tariffs on American whiskey.

Industry advocates are calling for a return to zero-for-zero tariffs on spirits, arguing that this would benefit American distillers, farmers, and the wider hospitality industry.

President Donald Trump announced his tariff plan on Wednesday, a day he dubbed "Liberation Day," that, across the board, includes a baseline tariff of 10% on essentially all other countries.

Additionally, Trump brought out a poster during the event in the White House Rose Garden to showcase specific tariffs on a variety of countries including: 34% tariff on China, 20% on the European Union, 46% on Vietnam, 32% on Taiwan, and 24% on Japan, among roughly a dozen other country specific tariffs.

As previously promised, Trump also levied a 25% tariff on foreign made automobiles, which will go into effect at midnight.

While alcohol products were not explicitly named as being tariffed, the blanket baseline tariff and country specific tariffs are likely to hit alcohol products made in foreign countries — which could prompt retaliatory tariffs that target American made products such as Kentucky bourbon.

U.S. Rep. Morgan McGarvey, D-Ky., told the Courier Journal: "I want to bring more manufacturing jobs home, but tariffs don't solve problems on their own. To work, they must be backed by a comprehensive plan...Donald Trump has not paired his overly broad, half-baked tariffs with any comprehensive strategy to return manufacturing jobs to the United States, and without one, these tariffs will only hurt working families and small businesses, while decimating Kentucky’s bourbon industry."

The tariffs, which Trump and political allies see as a key component in the "Make America Wealthy Again" movement, will be a "reciprocal tariff" program with the president stating, "they do it to us, we do it to them."

The tariffs were enacted through an Executive Order signed by Trump.

Trump said: "Today we are standing up for the American worker and we are finally putting America first."

Trump has repeatedly stated the goal of his tariff policy is to increase American manufacturing and encourage the onshoring and reshoring of industries to create more jobs for American workers.

Trump said: "Jobs and factories will come roaring back into our country."

The president believes the tariffs will "supercharge" the domestic industrial economy, "open foreign markets and break down foreign trade barriers," all of which he said will ultimately lead to "lower prices for consumers."

St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President and CEO Alberto Musalem, who oversees the region which includes Louisville and much of Kentucky, previously said businesses along the supply chain, ranging from raw materials to manufactured goods, will most likely pass the higher prices on to consumers when tariffs hit.

Bourbon, one of Kentucky's signature products, has been an easy target for retaliatory tariffs in the trade war waged by Trump.

With the announcement of baseline and country specific tariffs that are intended to hit products from foreign countries, retaliatory tariff could be placed on alcohol from the U.S., including American whiskey, the family to which bourbon belongs.

Chris Swonger, president of the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, DISCUS, said in a statement Wednesday: "We recognize that President Trump is working to secure fair and reciprocal trade and stand ready to work with the administration to untangle the spirits industry from the recent trade disputes so we can resume zero-for-zero trade with our major trading partners."

American spirits are a driving force of the U.S. hospitality industry economy, and intimately in Kentucky where bourbon is a $9 billion industry that crosses tourism, economic development and the restaurant industry.

Kentucky Democratic Party Chair Colmon Elridge said in a statement: "With these tariffs, President Trump is gambling with the lives of hard-working Kentuckians who are still waiting for him to fulfill his promise of lowering the cost of living 'on day one,'...Instead, he is doubling down on demands that have handcuffed our signature bourbon industry and jeopardized billions of dollars in trade with Kentucky’s top export markets, like Canada."

The U.S. spirits sector supports more than 1.7 million jobs.

Swonger previously told the Courier Journal that tariffs stand to harm these American workers and cause job losses from the farmers who grow the grains to the coopers who make the barrels to restaurant workers and more.

Swonger said: "We urge President Trump to liberate the U.S. spirits sector from these tariff disputes by negotiating deals that get us back to fair and reciprocal zero-for-zero tariffs for spirits products."

In 2018 during Trump's first presidency, tariffs he levied on steel and aluminum led to bourbon getting caught up in a trade war and facing retaliatory tariffs from the European Union. In the immediate aftermath while these EU tariffs were in place, American whiskey saw a decrease in exports.

Under President Joe Biden, a pause was negotiated on these tariffs, allowing for the American whiskey industry to start rebounding.

Swonger said: "The U.S. spirits sector has been the model of success for fair and reciprocal trade for decades. During the time that we had zero-for-zero tariffs with 51 countries, our industry flourished, benefitting U.S. distillers, farmers and the wider hospitality industry...A return to zero-for-zero tariffs with our key trading partners will enable the 3,100 distillers across the United States to partake in the limitless growth opportunities that exporting has to offer."

title: The ‘Bazooka’ Europe Could Use to Fight Trump’s Tariffs - (Published 17 hour(s), 42 minute(s) ago)
content: European officials are weighing deploying a tool called the anti-coercion instrument that would potentially target American tech and financial giants.
resumen:
En la creciente guerra comercial con Estados Unidos, los funcionarios europeos están discutiendo la imposición de barreras a las importaciones de servicios estadounidenses con un arma comercial que podría permitir al bloque restringir a las grandes empresas tecnológicas y a Wall Street.

Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea, dijo esta semana: "Tenemos el poder de contraatacar".

El presidente Trump ya ha anunciado aranceles sobre el aluminio, el acero, los automóviles y las autopartes, medidas que podrían perjudicar seriamente la inestable economía del bloque. Bruselas ha respondido anunciando que reimpondría gravámenes a las importaciones estadounidenses como las motocicletas Harley-Davidson, el whisky y otros bienes, algunos de los cuales fueron objeto de ataques durante el enfrentamiento transatlántico que el Sr. Trump instigó en su primer mandato.

Para contrarrestar los últimos aranceles recíprocos del Sr. Trump, los funcionarios europeos están considerando desplegar una herramienta política llamada instrumento anti-coerción, al que algunos se refieren como una "bazuca". El instrumento, que se adoptó en 2023 para responder a China pero nunca se utilizó, se considera una opción de último recurso si las conversaciones con la administración Trump van mal.

Bruselas podría adaptar la herramienta para atacar a los gigantes tecnológicos y las instituciones financieras de Estados Unidos. Un plan externo que ha estado circulando en las últimas semanas incluye una opción nuclear: limitar el acceso de los bancos estadounidenses al enorme mercado de contratación pública de la Unión Europea, lo que significaría cortar parcialmente a los bancos de proyectos por valor de aproximadamente 2 billones de euros (2,2 billones de dólares) cada año.

Otra idea en el plan preliminar es atacar las enormes sumas que los europeos invierten anualmente en empresas estadounidenses, un flujo anual de aproximadamente 300.000 millones de euros que se ha convertido en un punto de irritación para los funcionarios de la UE. Y finalmente, el plan preliminar dice que Bruselas "también podría aumentar la presión fiscal y regulatoria sobre las plataformas digitales estadounidenses".

El plan no aclaró el alcance, y mucho menos cómo se podría implementar alguna de las dos propuestas. Pero mostró cuán ampliamente están pensando los asesores políticos mientras el bloque sopesa su enfoque.

"Personalmente, creo que la gran bazuca debería usarse en primer lugar como elemento disuasorio", dijo Fabrizio Pagani, socio del banco de inversión Vitale y ex alto funcionario económico del gobierno italiano, refiriéndose a la herramienta anti-coerción. "Así que pónganla sobre la mesa y negociemos".

Olof Gill, portavoz de la Comisión Europea, dijo que el instrumento anti-coerción se estaba considerando mientras Bruselas traza su estrategia de negociación. Un punto es que, aunque la Unión Europea ha acumulado un gran superávit comercial en bienes, al mismo tiempo ha acumulado un déficit comercial de aproximadamente 110.000 millones de euros en servicios con Estados Unidos. Explotar ese punto podría ser clave en las negociaciones, dicen los asesores.

Pero algunos analistas y economistas temen que una negociación tan dura pueda ser contraproducente.

"Los aranceles sobre los servicios, al igual que los aranceles sobre los bienes, afectan directamente a los consumidores y a las empresas", dijo Joachim Klement, jefe de estrategia del banco de inversión Panmure Liberum, y agregó que sería una forma segura de escalar la guerra comercial.

"Simplemente estás echando leña al fuego de la estanflación", agregó.

title: India sees opportunity, as well as risk, in Trump’s trade war - (Published 21 hour(s), 34 minute(s) ago)
content: Although that is manageable for Mr Modi in the short term, it comes as the economy is slowing and the stockmarket slumping. A long trade war could undermine his goal of boosting India’s exports to ...
resumen:
India faces a watershed moment. On April 2nd, Mr. Trump unveiled “reciprocal” tariffs on America’s trade partners, including a 27% levy on Indian goods. Indian officials suggest India can weather any short-term pain and quickly agree to a trade deal with America that would unleash growth. Privately many worry that any deal would face fierce resistance at home. A drawn-out trade war could jeopardize the ambitious economic and political agenda of the prime minister, Narendra Modi.

India had tried to appease Mr. Trump by reducing tariffs on goods including bourbon and motorbikes before Mr. Modi visited Washington in February. The two leaders agreed to complete the first part of a trade deal by this autumn and to try to expand bilateral goods and services trade to $500bn by 2030 (from $210bn in 2024). They also agreed that India would buy more American oil, gas and arms to help cut its big bilateral trade surplus.

Piyush Goyal, India’s commerce minister, visited Washington in March and offered to cut more tariffs. India widened its offer to cover some 55% of American exports to India. It also scrapped a 6% tax on digital advertisements. Two telecoms operators, Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel, struck deals to bring Elon Musk’s Starlink satellite-internet service to India.

India’s commerce ministry said on March 29th that the two sides had reached “an understanding on the next steps”. The apparent aim is to reach a goods-trade deal as early as August, with one on services to follow.

The new tariffs’ direct impact on India’s economy will be limited. Bilateral goods trade with America is around 3% of India’s GDP. Ajay Srivastava, a former Indian trade official who heads the Global Trade Research Initiative, suggests India could benefit from the higher tariffs on several other Asian countries, noting that pharmaceuticals, a big Indian export to America, were exempted.

America is India’s largest export market and the tariffs could strain individual sectors that are big employers, such as agriculture. The worst-affected sectors are likely to include seafood, as well as gems and jewellery, says Mr. Srivastava. The tariffs could also hit India’s exports of electronics, including locally assembled iPhones and other smartphones. India’s main share indices opened lower on April 3rd, with technology stocks hit hardest, while pharmaceuticals rallied.

Economists reckon that the tariffs, which were higher than expected, could cut India’s growth by around 0.8 percentage points.

A long trade war could undermine his goal of boosting India’s exports to $2trn by 2030 from $778bn in 2023-24 and accelerating annual GDP growth to at least 8%.

Since he took power in 2014 India has increased tariffs as part of his campaign to develop domestic manufacturing. It has also offered production-linked incentives (PLIs), rewarding companies that lift output over a baseline, to attract foreign manufacturers. Quality-control orders, non-tariff barriers that supposedly impose safety standards on imports, have proliferated too.

Domestic manufacturing languishes at 14% of GDP, down from 16% in 2015. Private investment has stagnated and foreign direct investment has gone into reverse. Reuters, a news agency, reported on March 24th that the PLI scheme would be allowed to lapse. Mr. Goyal recently warned Indian exporters to shed their “protectionist mindset”. Having walked away from a big regional trade deal in 2019, India is now negotiating deals with the EU and Britain as well.

Mr. Trump may push India to open government procurement to American firms and remove restrictions on data flows—demands India has long resisted.

title: ‘We are in a trade war’: Washington leaders, business sectors largely express confusion and concern at Trump’s sweeping tariff announcement - (Published 7 hour(s), 51 minute(s) ago)
content: Washington is uniquely positioned to feel the negative impacts of a trade war spurred by a host of new tariffs, several statewide officials said this week.
resumen:
On April 2, 2025, The Spokesman-Review reported on the reactions of Washington leaders and business sectors to President Donald Trump's announcement of sweeping tariffs.

Lt. Gov. Denny Heck stated that Washington is the most trade-driven state economy and would be disproportionately affected by the tariffs. He also mentioned that the tariffs could damage the state's economy. Heck, who serves as Chair of Washington’s Legislative Committee on Economic Development and International Relations, has led trade missions to Canada, Mexico, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom. He also served as vice-chair of the Export-Import Bank of the United States Advisory Council. Heck said that Trump's plan to tariff exports to boost domestic production is "really faulty" and that the zig-zagging on tariffs is the opposite of stability.

Dave Reich, the state’s chief economist, said there was an “elevated level of risk” in the forecast due to changes in trade policy. He added that tariffs are a negative to “the national economy and the local economy.”

Heck expressed concern about the state’s agricultural industry. He stated that the announcement was a declaration of a trade war. He also said he "would not be surprised" if many economists throughout the world opted to raise their projections of a recession this year.

Gov. Bob Ferguson said Washington’s economy could be hit hard by a potential tariff war.

Casey Chumrau, CEO of the Washington State Grain Commission, said it wasn’t clear what effect tariffs would have on the state’s markets. China now faces a 54% tariff rate, the Philippines (17%), Japan (24%), South Korea (25%), and Indonesia (32%).

Chris Stone, deputy director of the Washington State Wine Commission, said there was more confusion than answers. Canada is the biggest foreign destination for Washington’s wine.

The Trump administration has imposed a 25% tariff on foreign-made vehicles that takes effect Thursday and similar tariff rates on foreign automotive parts starting May 3.

Vicki Fabre, executive vice president for the Washington State Auto Dealers Association, raised concerns that increased tariffs could make it more difficult for consumers to afford new and used vehicles. Estimates range from $2,000 to over $10,000 per vehicle.

Isaiah Paine, public affairs and strategic office for the Spokane Home Builders Association, noted that the industry estimates about 7% of all goods used in residential construction are foreign-sourced, including 30% of softwood lumber and 30% of appliances.

Britt La Chance, CEO of Liberty Lake-based Premier Manufacturing, said that the tariffs will increase demand for U.S. manufacturing.

Edmund O. Schweitzer III, founder of Pullman-headquartered Schweitzer Engineering Laboratories, expressed concerns with tariffs.

title: Perú espera que el TLC con EEUU le ampare de los aranceles del 10 % impuestos por Trump - (Published 13 hour(s), 58 minute(s) ago)
content: Lima, 2 abr (EFE).- El Gobierno peruano confía en que el Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) firmado con Estados Unidos en 2009 amparará al país de los aranceles del 10 % impuestos por el presidente estad ...
resumen: El Gobierno peruano confía en que el Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC) firmado con Estados Unidos en 2009 amparará al país de los aranceles del 10 % impuestos por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. El primer ministro de Perú, Gustavo Adrianzén, dijo que esperan conocer en detalle el contenido de esta decisión para poder tomar la temperatura exactamente. Perú forma parte del grupo de países latinoamericanos que estarán sujetos a un arancel del 10 % impuesto por Trump a toda la región, con excepción de México, Venezuela y Nicaragua, a los cuales aplicará tasas más elevadas, en concreto del 15 % y el 18 %, respectivamente. Adrianzén detalló que su Gobierno no tiene precisión "exactamente a qué productos está afectando" y "algunas voces" le han dicho que "se trata de automóviles". Estados Unidos es un socio comercial muy importante para Perú. La economía del país suramericano "es abierta al mercado" y siempre tiene "la posibilidad de buscar nuevos mercados o ampliar" aquellos a los que ya tienen acceso. Estados Unidos es el segundo socio comercial de Perú, después de China, y, al cierre de 2024, las exportaciones al país norteamericano fueron el 12,6 % del total a nivel global. Trump incluyó a Perú en el grupo de países a los que ha impuesto un arancel del 10 %, mientras que estos impuestos serán del 34 % para China y del 20 % para la Unión Europea (UE). El mandatario justificó esta medida porque, según dijo, tanto Perú como otros países de la región latinoamericana y del mundo contemplan aranceles del 10 % para productos estadounidenses.

title: Panamá - Estados Unidos: ¿Los aranceles de Trump afectan a Panamá? - (Published 10 hour(s), 28 minute(s) ago)
content: Donald Trump declaró la guerra comercial al mundo y Panamá no se salva. En el caso de la región centroamericana el mandatario estadounidense anunció que aplicaría aranceles de un 10%. ¿Cómo nos afecta ...
resumen: Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos, anunció que aplicaría aranceles de un 10% a la región centroamericana. Panamá importó a Estados Unidos un total de 184.5 millones de dólares en 2024, y en lo que va de 2025, 12.9 millones de dólares. Los productos del mar y los bananos son los productos que Panamá más vende en Estados Unidos. Lista de productos que exporta Panamá a Estados Unidos: bananas, crustáceos, alcohol etílico, aceite de palma, desperdicios y desechos (Chatarra y hierro viejo), madera en bruto, medicamentos. Los nuevos aranceles entrarán en vigor el 5 y el 9 de abril. Las nuevas tarifas aduaneras a las importaciones se aplicarán en dos fases: el 5 de abril a las 04:01 GMT para aquellas de al menos el 10% sobre todos los productos que entran en Estados Unidos, y el 9 de abril a las 04:01 GMT para aquellos más altos dirigidos contra gigantes como China y la Unión Europea. Trump anunció aranceles del 34% para los bienes chinos, 20% para los de la Unión Europea y 46% para los de Vietnam. 10% para los productos de Brasil, Colombia, Argentina, Chile, Perú, Costa Rica, República Dominicana, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras y El Salvador que entren en Estados Unidos. Aplicará tarifas aduaneras del 18% a los bienes de Nicaragua. México y Canadá se libran de los nuevos aranceles, pero siguen sometidos a los anunciados para incitarlos a combatir la migración ilegal y el tráfico de fentanilo, lo que significa el 25% de aranceles (10% para los hidrocarburos canadienses) salvo los productos contemplados en el Tratado de Libre Comercio de América del Norte (T-MEC).

title: El mundo reacciona a los nuevos aranceles de Trump - (Published 7 hour(s), 53 minute(s) ago)
content: Las siguientes son las reacciones mundiales al anuncio del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, de imponer mayores aranceles a China, Europa y numerosos países latinoamericanos, incluidos Brasil, ...
resumen:
Las reacciones mundiales al anuncio del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, de imponer mayores aranceles a China, Europa y numerosos países latinoamericanos, incluidos Brasil, Colombia, Argentina, Chile, Perú, Costa Rica, República Dominicana, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras y El Salvador:

*   **Brasil:** El Congreso de Brasil aprobó por unanimidad un proyecto que otorga herramientas al Ejecutivo para responder a las barreras comerciales de Trump. La "ley de reciprocidad económica" fue avalada el miércoles por la Cámara de Diputados, tras recibir un día antes el visto bueno del Senado.
*   **Colombia:** El presidente colombiano, Gustavo Petro, publicó en la red social X que los nuevos gravámenes estadounidenses pueden ser "un gran error". Su país enfrenta un aumento arancelario del 10%.
*   **Canadá:** El primer ministro de Canadá, Mark Carney, advirtió que "Vamos a combatir estos aranceles con contramedidas", consideró que las tarifas estadounidenses "cambiarán fundamentalmente el sistema de comercio mundial" y "afectarán directamente a millones de canadienses".
*   **Australia:** El primer ministro australiano, Anthony Albanese, expresó que "Estos aranceles no son inesperados, pero déjenme ser claro: son totalmente injustificados" y afirmó que "no son el acto de un amigo".
*   **Alemania:** La industria automovilística alemana advirtió que estos gravámenes estadounidenses "solo crearán perdedores". La Asociación Alemana de Industria Automotriz indicó que "La Unión Europea debe actuar ahora de manera unida y con la fuerza necesaria mientras continúa indicando su disposición de negociar".
*   **Reino Unido:** El ministro británico de Comercio, Jonathan Reynolds, expresó su intención de alcanzar un acuerdo comercial con Estados Unidos para, al menos, mitigar el impacto de las tarifas de Trump, aunque advirtió que su país tiene "una extensa gama de herramientas" a su disposición y no dudará "en actuar".
*   **Italia:** La primera ministra italiana, Giorgia Meloni, reaccionó que "La introducción por parte de Estados Unidos de aranceles a la UE (Unión Europea) es una medida que considero mala y que no conviene a ninguna parte". Agregó que "Haré todo lo que pueda para trabajar por un acuerdo con Estados Unidos, buscando evitar una guerra comercial que inevitablemente debilitará a Occidente en provecho de otros actores mundiales".

title: Guatemala cree que «hay que esperar» para ver «el alcance» de los nuevos aranceles de EEUU - (Published 8 hour(s), 29 minute(s) ago)
content: Ciudad de Guatemala, 2 abr (EFE).- El Gobierno de Guatemala afirmó este miércoles que "hay que esperar" para ver "el alcance" de los nuevos aranceles anunciados hoy por Estados Unidos, que en el caso ...
resumen: El Gobierno de Guatemala afirmó que «hay que esperar» para ver «el alcance» de los nuevos aranceles anunciados hoy por Estados Unidos, que en el caso del país centroamericano serán del 10 %. El Ministerio de Economía guatemalteco indicó en un comunicado que se encuentran analizando la «orden ejecutiva» del Gobierno de Donald Trump, que impone nuevos aranceles del 10 % a los productos a exportar desde la nación que preside Bernardo Arévalo de León. El Ministerio de Economía expuso que para comprender el alcance y la base de los aranceles hay que esperar a que se publique la orden ejecutiva. La cartera que dirige Gabriela García, aseveró que mantiene una «coordinación estrecha» con su embajada en Washington y también «una línea de comunicación con el sector privado» debido a los nuevos aranceles establecidos este miércoles. Guatemala exportó productos a Estados Unidos en 2024 por un valor de 4.614 millones de dólares (unos 4.232 millones de euros), mientras que las importaciones desde la nación norteamericana ascendieron a 10.542 millones de dólares (nos 9.668 millones de euros). El Ministerio de Economía guatemalteco recordó que la decisión de este miércoles por parte de Estados Unidos viola los acuerdos que forman parte del Tratado de Libre Comercio vigente entre la nación norteamericana y Centroamérica en conjunto con República Dominicana. Considera que la medida será llevada a cabo por Estados Unidos bajo los lineamientos de su política nacional de seguridad. Trump compareció este miércoles para dar los detalles de la esperada batería de gravámenes que impondrá en «represalia» por las barreras que se impone a las exportaciones estadounidenses en todo el mundo. El arancel base para todos es del 10 %, incluido el de Guatemala.

title: Brasil lamenta aranceles anunciados por Trump y afirma que viola compromisos con la OMC - (Published 7 hour(s), 48 minute(s) ago)
content: Brasilia, 2 abr (Xinhua) -- El Gobierno de Brasil lamentó este miércoles la decisión adoptada por Estados Unidos de imponer aranceles adicionales del 10 por ciento a todas las exportaciones brasileñas ...
resumen: El Gobierno de Brasil lamentó la decisión de Estados Unidos de imponer aranceles adicionales del 10 por ciento a todas las exportaciones brasileñas a ese país. Esta medida viola los compromisos de Estados Unidos ante la Organización Mundial del Comercio y afectará todas las exportaciones brasileñas de bienes hacia los EEUU. El superávit comercial de Estados Unidos con Brasil en 2024 fue del orden de 7.000 millones de dólares, solo en bienes, y alcanzó los 28.600 millones de dólares el año pasado si se suman bienes y servicios. En los últimos 15 años, Estados Unidos ha registrado superávits comerciales con Brasil por un total de 410.000 millones de dólares. El Gobierno brasileño buscará defender los intereses de los productores nacionales ante el Gobierno estadounidense y está evaluando todas las posibles vías de acción para garantizar la reciprocidad en el comercio bilateral, incluyendo el recurso a la Organización Mundial del Comercio. El Gobierno brasileño destacó la aprobación por el Senado de un proyecto de Ley de Reciprocidad Económica.

title: Aranceles de Trump: estos son los principales productos que exporta Colombia a EEUU - (Published 10 hour(s), 7 minute(s) ago)
content: El presidente Donald Trump anunció aranceles del 20 % para las importaciones de la Unión Europea (UE) y del 10 % para varios países latinoamericanos, incluyendo Colombia. Estos son los datos.
resumen: El presidente Donald Trump anunció aranceles del 20 % para las importaciones de la Unión Europea (UE) y del 10 % para varios países latinoamericanos, incluyendo Colombia. El presidente Donald Trump publicó la lista de países a los que les impondría aranceles, entre ellos Colombia con un 10 %. También están Argentina, Brasil, Perú y otros. Colombia y Estados Unidos mantienen un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC), el cual entró en vigor en el 2012, y que EEUU es el principal socio comercial. Trump anuncia aranceles del 10 % para Argentina, Brasil, Colombia y Chile. Entre los principales destinos de exportación de Colombia en lo corrido del 2025, EEUU está a la cabeza con el 28.8 % y un crecimiento, hasta ahora, del 9.8 %, según cifras de la Asociación Nacional de Comercio Exterior (Andalex). Les sigue la Unión Europea, Panamá, Ecuador, Países Bajos, India, Brasil, China, Perú y destinos de zonas francas. Principales productos que exporta Colombia a EEUU: Petróleo, Oro, Café sin tostar, Flores, Puertas y ventanas, Aceites crudos, Bananas o plátanos. De acuerdo con Andalex, el incremento del valor de exportaciones colombianas en lo que va del año se explica por esta razón: el aumento de las ventas de productos como el café, té, cacao, especias y sus preparados (86.0 %). También aceites esenciales y resinoides, productos de perfumería (14.4 %), oro no monetario (31.6 %) y menas y desechos de metales (73.0 %). En febrero, las exportaciones de Colombia cayeron hasta en el 0.8 %. Andalex detalló que las ventas externas registraron una disminución frente al nivel del mismo mes del 2024. El peso exportado cayó un 18.9 %, “ubicándose en 6.9 millones de toneladas métricas”. México y Canadá se salvaron de los nuevos aranceles que anunció el presidente Trump este miércoles.

title: Venezuela no se salvó de la imposición de aranceles por parte de Donald Trump y el porcentaje será más alto que el de Colombia - (Published 9 hour(s), 42 minute(s) ago)
content: El presidente estadounidense mostró una tabla de aranceles recíprocos contra China, la Unión Europea y varios países de Latinoamérica.
resumen:

La ofensiva de la Casa Blanca consiste en una tarifa aduanera mínima del 10% para todas las importaciones, a lo que se añaden recargos para ciertos países considerados particularmente hostiles en términos comerciales.
Los aranceles serán del 24% para Japón, el 26% para la India y el 31% para Suiza.
Varias economías latinoamericanas figuran en el listado: Brasil, Colombia, Argentina, Chile, Perú, Costa Rica, República Dominicana, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras y El Salvador. Aplicará el 10% a todas sus importaciones. El índice será más alto para Nicaragua: el 18% y Venezuela tendrá el 15%.
Las nuevas tarifas aduaneras se aplicarán en dos fases: el 5 de abril a las 04H01 GMT entrarán en vigor aquellas de al menos el 10% sobre todos los productos que entran en Estados Unidos, y el 9 de abril a las 04H01 las más altas.

title: Nuevos aranceles de EE.UU. generan incertidumbre al Gobierno y exportadores de Costa Rica - (Published 7 hour(s), 53 minute(s) ago)
content: San José, 2 abr (EFE).- Los nuevos aranceles anunciados este miércoles por Estados Unidos para los productos de casi todo el mundo y que para los de Costa Rica se fijaron en un 10 %, han generado ince ...
resumen:
Los nuevos aranceles anunciados este miércoles por Estados Unidos para los productos de casi todo el mundo y que para los de Costa Rica se fijaron en un 10 %, han generado incertidumbre en los exportadores y en el Gobierno del país centroamericano, que ha anunciado que buscará un diálogo bilateral al respecto.

El Gobierno costarricense ha informado que desconoce los alcances de la medida, si los aranceles se impondrán a todos los productos o si solo para algunos en específico, por lo cual está en procura de recabar la información oficial respectiva.

El Ministerio de Comercio Exterior de Costa Rica indicó que entablará un diálogo con las autoridades de Estados Unidos para procurar las mejores condiciones de acceso a los productos costarricenses.

El presidente de Costa Rica, Rodrigo Chaves, dijo brevemente que es necesario estudiar el asunto para emitir un pronunciamiento, pero sí manifestó que su país es uno de los que ha recibido un arancel más bajo.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, compareció este miércoles para dar los detalles de la esperada batería de gravámenes que impondrá en «represalia» por las barreras que se impone a las exportaciones estadounidenses en todo el mundo.

El presidente de la Cámara de Exportadores de Costa Rica (Cadexco), Víctor Pérez, reconoció que «todavía no está claro a cuáles productos se están aplicando los aranceles».

Pérez explicó que es posible que el consumo de algún producto baje en Estados Unidos porque se pueda encarecer.

El empresario hizo un llamado al Gobierno costarricense para «seguir trabajando en la competitividad de Costa Rica, en infraestructura, talento humano y tipo de cambio del dólar para poder ser lo suficientemente competitivo y continuar llevando nuestros productos al mundo».

Estados Unidos es el principal socio comercial de Costa Rica, al dirigir hacia ese mercado el 46 % de las exportaciones costarricenses. Es la mayor fuente de inversión extranjera directa y además el principal emisor de turistas.

Costa Rica forma parte del Tratado de Libre Comercio entre Centroamérica, República Dominicana y Estados Unidos (CAFTA-DR), firmado a inicios de la década del 2000 y que en territorio costarricense entró en vigencia en 2007 tras ser aprobado por la población en un referéndum.
